titleStmt.title:
AN
INVITATION to DINNER,
FROM
DOCTOR SHERIDAN to DOCTOR SWIFT.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Written in the Year M DCC XXVII.
I'VE sent to the ladies ·Mrs. Johnson [Stella] and her friend Mrs. Dingley. this morning, to warn 'em
To order their chaise, and repair to ·A village near Dublin, where Dr. Sheridan had a country-house. Rathfarnam;
Where you shall be welcome to dine, if your Deanship
Can take up with me, and my friend Stella's leanship·Stella was at this time in a very declining state of health. She died the January following..
I've got you some soals, and a fresh bleeding bret,
That's just disengag'd from the toils of a net:
An excellent loin of fat veal to be roasted,
With lemons, and butter, and sippets well toasted:
Some larks that descended, mistaking the skies,
Which Stella brought down by the light of her eyes;
And there, like Narcissus, they gaz'd till they dy'd,
And now they're to lie in some·some crumbs that are fry'd.
My wine will inspire you with joy and delight.
'Tis mellow, and old, and sparkling and bright;
An emblem of one that you love I suppose,
Who gathers more lovers the older she grows.·He means Stella, who was certainly one of the most amiable women in the world.
Let me be your Gay, and let Stella be Pope,
We'll wean you from sighing for England, I hope:
When we are together there's nothing that is dull,
There's nothing like Durfey, or Smedley, or Tisdall.·A Gentleman of wit and learning, who had written some very sarcastic verses upon Sheridan.
We've sworn to make out an agreeable feast,
Our dinner, our wine, and our wit to your taste.
Your answer in half an hour, tho' you are at Prayers; you have a Pencil in your Pocket.
